courseDescription:
Are you studying for an exam on business organisations and need some guidance? This online course on business organisation forms will guide and equip you with the necessary knowledge. It begins by identifying the different types of business arrangements existing in the business world. Then, from sole proprietorship and partnerships to an explanation of the Joint Hindu Family system, you will be given an in-depth analysis of each.

Do you want to know the different cooperative societies and their potential benefits? The course will take you through the concept of cooperative societies and their different types. You will also be going through their merits and limitations in a business context to provide you with a complete understanding. We will also discuss the ease of setting up cooperative societies and the relevant legal requirements.

Are you curious about the differences between public and private companies? We provide an in-depth analysis of joint stock companies. First, we discuss the setting up process, the legal requirements and the potential benefits of each type of company in detail. Then, having studied the different types of business arrangements, we lay out a comparative analysis of each type and which you should choose based on the given circumstances.   • Lesson Summary
  • Below you will find a summary of the key content covered during the module:
    • Sole proprietorship refers to a business organisation which is owned, managed and controlled by a single individual. 
    • In a sole proprietorship, there is no legal distinction between the individual and the business owner. The owner owns all the assets and is responsible for the debts and liabilities. 
    • Sole proprietors have unlimited liability and because only one person controls it, they usually lack business continuity.
    • A joint Hindu family business is a specific form of business only found in India. It is a form of organisation which is owned and carried on by members of a joint Hindu family.
    • A joint Hindu family business is controlled by the head of the family who is also known as the Karta. All members in a Hindu family system have a legal right over ancestral property and are known as co-parceners.
    • A partnership consists of two or more people who combine their resources to form a business and agree to share the risks and rewards. The liability of every partner is unlimited.
    • A partner who only contributes capital to the partnership but does not take part in the day-to-day activities of the business is called a sleeping partner. 
    • Different types of partners can have different participation in management, share in profit or loss and liability status.

  • Lesson Summary
  • Below you will find a summary of the key content covered during the module:
    • A cooperative society is often a voluntary association of individuals who come together with the intention to work together and to promote their economic interest.
    • There are different types of co-operative societies registered under the Co-operative Societies Act, of 1912. A few are as follows: Housing society, consumer society, agricultural marketing society.
    • The cooperative society is a separate entity under the Income Tax Act of 1961.
    • Membership in a cooperative society is voluntary. It is also a separate legal entity after registration. In a cooperative society, the power to take decisions lies in the hands of an elected managing committee. 
    • A cooperative society is easy to form and has plenty of concessions and privileges from the government. However, it can also be limited due to too much government control and a lack of secrecy in settling matters. 
    • Consumer cooperative societies are formed to protect the interests of consumers and promote their welfare. 
    • Credit cooperative societies are established to provide easy credit to members at a lower rate of interest.
    • Cooperative housing societies are established to help people with limited income to construct houses at a lower cost.

  • Lesson Summary
  • Below you will find a summary of the key content covered during the module:
    • A joint-stock company is a business owned by its investors, with each investor owning a share based on the amount of stock purchased.
    • If the joint-stock company is public, its shares are traded on registered stock exchanges.
    • The term joint-stock company is virtually synonymous with a corporation, public company, or just plain company, except for a historical association with unlimited liability.
    • Joint-stock companies can raise a large amount of capital by issuing shares, rather than relying on a single investor.
    • A joint stock company can be difficult to form as there are plenty of legal requirements that need to be fulfilled.
    •  Since joint stock companies are managed by a board of directors, decision-making can be a slow process with approvals taking time.
    • The easiest form of business to set up is sole proprietorship as it has the least amount of cost and legal requirements. 
    • A joint stock company generally has the largest amount of financial resources due to the pool of funds available.
